Claude Code EAP Report

The Explorer and the Executor: How Two Opus Models Solve Differently

A single-user comparative study across 2,395 tasks examining behavioral divergence between Opus 4.5 and Opus 4.6
Samuel H. Christie V · February 2026 · Claude Code Early Access Program

1. Executive Summary

Per-Task Cost Gap
−9 to −45%
4.6 cheaper at every complexity level
Output Token Ratio
2.7×
4.6: 2,481 avg vs 4.5: 919 avg
Strongest Signal
Tool usage
+55% tools/task (p<0.000003)
User Corrections
0.6%
Opus 4.6 vs 8.9% for Opus 4.5
Key takeaway: Opus 4.6 produces 2.7× more output tokens, uses 55% more tool calls, deploys 3× more subagents, and plans 10× more often—yet costs 9–45% less per task through better prompt caching and fewer API round-trips. Users correct Opus 4.5 edits 16× more often (8.9% vs 0.6%), the strongest accuracy signal in the dataset. Of 105 statistical tests, only three survive Bonferroni correction—all about how each model works (tool usage, alignment score), not whether they succeed. The models are strategically different, not meaningfully different in quality.

Opus 4.5 acts first and adjusts as needed; Opus 4.6 investigates first and implements in concentrated bursts. This report examines where these two strategies diverge across 2,395 tasks (2,035 vs 360). Sections are ordered by effect strength: robust findings (cost efficiency, tool usage) first, weaker signals (satisfaction, parallelism) later.

Contents & Key Findings
  1. Token Economy & Cost4.6 is 9–45% cheaper despite 2.7× more output tokens
  2. Complexity-Controlled ComparisonTool usage gap is the strongest statistical signal (p<0.000003)
  3. Behavioral Patterns4.6 deploys 3× more subagents, 72% read-only Explore agents
  4. Session Dynamics4.6 benefits from session context; both degrade in long sessions
  5. Quality & SatisfactionBoth under 0.4% dissatisfaction; completion and failure rates differ
  6. Parallelization4.5 spawns more agents; only 4.6 runs them in the background
  7. Edit AccuracyUsers correct 4.5 edits 16× more often; self-correction rates comparable
  8. Planning: Correlation vs Causation10× more planning, only +0.04 alignment benefit
  9. Model ProfilesRouting recommendations for each model
  10. MethodologyPipeline, development process, and limitations

2. Token Economy & Cost

Extracting API usage data from session logs reveals how each model allocates its computational budget. The two models achieve similar per-task costs through radically different token strategies.

Per-Task Cost
~$2.40
$2.30 (4.5) vs $2.49 (4.6)
Output Token Ratio
2.7×
4.6 produces 2,481 vs 919 avg tokens
Thinking Depth Gap
+41%
3,476 vs 2,459 chars when thinking
Total Cost Analyzed
$5,472
$4,575 (4.5) + $897 (4.6)

Thinking Calibration

Opus 4.5 thinks more often (78% of tasks) but shallowly. Opus 4.6 thinks less often (59%) but more deeply when it does. The pattern reverses at the complexity extremes:

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6

Major — thinking %

82%

100%
 82% 100% +18pp
Thinking calibration: Opus 4.6 shows better calibration of when thinking is needed. It skips thinking for 71% of trivial tasks (vs 34% for Opus 4.5), but engages thinking for 100% of major tasks (vs 82%). Opus 4.5 over-thinks easy problems and occasionally under-thinks hard ones.

Output Verbosity by Task Type

Task Type4.5 avg output4.6 avg output4.6/4.5
Refactor1,1667,3396.3×
Greenfield1,7306,2783.6×
Bug fix8742,8973.3×
Investigation9282,4632.7×
Feature1,4313,2192.2×
Sysadmin6599621.5×
Port2,5253,5991.4×
Continuation7857521.0×

The 6.3× multiplier for refactoring is the most extreme: Opus 4.6 spends significantly more tokens exploring the codebase before making changes. For continuation tasks (follow-ups within a session), both models produce identical output volume—suggesting the verbosity gap comes from initial exploration, not ongoing work.

Cost by Complexity

Complexity4.5 avg cost4.6 avg costΔ
Trivial$0.73$0.40−45%
Simple$2.18$1.81−17%
Moderate$3.54$3.16−11%
Complex$7.72$7.00−9%
Major$16.79$14.46−14%
Counter-intuitive cost finding: Despite producing 2–6× more output tokens, Opus 4.6 is 9–45% cheaper per task at every complexity level. The savings come from more efficient prompt caching and fewer API round-trips. Opus 4.6 averages 21.5 tool calls per task (more work per request) vs 13.9 for Opus 4.5 (more requests with less work each).

Opus 4.6 sessions skew toward higher complexity: fewer trivial tasks (42% vs 52%) and proportionally more complex and major tasks. This makes raw aggregate comparisons misleading—Opus 4.6 is tackling harder work on average.

Resource Usage

MetricDistribution4.54.6Δ
Avg tools per task

Statistical significance: Tool calls per task (p=0.000002, d=−0.29) and tools per file (p=0.000003, d=−0.18) are the strongest signals in this study—both survive Bonferroni correction. Lines-added difference is not significant.
The exploration–satisfaction tradeoff: Opus 4.6 uses 55% more tool calls and touches 47% more files per task, yet produces only 12% more lines of code. The extra activity is research, not output. This research correlates with higher alignment (+0.26) and completion (+6.2pp), but the marginal value of each additional tool call diminishes—55% more effort yields a small-effect improvement.

 3 16 B +6.8pp
The invisible subagent: Opus 4.6 deploys more total subagents (186 vs 169) yet they feel invisible to the user. The reason: 72% are lightweight, read-only Explore agents that quietly gather context before implementation begins. Opus 4.5 inverts this ratio—50% of its subagents are general-purpose implementation workers that visibly modify files. The models produce comparable output, but Opus 4.6 front-loads research while Opus 4.5 front-loads action.
Statistical significance: Autonomy level (p=0.007, V=0.10) and one-shot rate (p=0.004, h=−0.16) significant at p<0.05 but not after Bonferroni correction. The behavioral differences are large but reflect model design rather than statistical surprise.

5. Session Dynamics

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6

Warm-up Effects

PhaseAlignment (4.5 / 4.6)Completion (4.5 / 4.6)Tools/File (4.5 / 4.6)
Early (first 3 tasks) 2.85 / 2.95 24.2% / 25.0% 4.95 / 5.68
Later (task 4+) 2.85 / 3.06 28.0% / 33.5% 4.50 / 5.11

Opus 4.5 shows no warm-up effect: alignment stays flat at 2.85 between early and later tasks. Opus 4.6 improves from 2.95 to 3.06 in alignment and from 25.0% to 33.5% in completion rate, suggesting it benefits more from accumulated session context.

Effort Distribution

MetricDistribution4.54.6
Research ratio
A
28.3%
B
35.1%
 0.283 0.351
Implementation ratio
A
27.0%
B
17.5%
 0.270 0.175
Front-load positive %
A
54.3%
B
59.3%
 868 tasks 194 tasks
Research-first vs balanced: Opus 4.6 allocates 35% of tool calls to research (Read, Grep, Glob, Explore agents) vs 28% for Opus 4.5, with a correspondingly lower implementation ratio (17.5% vs 27.0%). Opus 4.6 also front-loads research more aggressively—59.3% of tasks show positive front-loading vs 54.3%. It investigates first, then implements in concentrated bursts.

Session Length Effects

Session LengthAlignment (4.5 / 4.6)Completion (4.5 / 4.6)Sessions (4.5 / 4.6)
Short (1–3 tasks)2.93 / 3.5333.3% / 41.7%135 / 26
Medium (4–8 tasks)2.93 / 3.1630.3% / 37.4%45 / 27
Long (9+ tasks)2.85 / 2.9627.0% / 28.6%58 / 11
Statistical significance: Duration (p=0.015, d=−0.02) and iteration rate (p=0.018, V=0.10) significant at p<0.05 but not after Bonferroni correction. Session-length effects are observational and confounded with task selection.

Both models degrade in longer sessions, but Opus 4.6 degrades more steeply: from 3.53 to 2.96 in alignment (−0.57) vs 2.93 to 2.85 (−0.08) for Opus 4.5. However, Opus 4.6 scores higher than Opus 4.5 in every session-length bucket—even in long sessions (2.96 vs 2.85). The steeper decline reflects 4.6’s higher baseline, not a crossover where 4.5 becomes preferable.

B
7.5%
 271 27 B −5.8pp

Opus 4.6 completes a higher fraction of tasks outright (+6.2pp) and fails less often (−5.8pp). The failure rate difference is statistically significant (p=0.002) though the effect size is negligible (Cohen's h=0.19). Both models interrupt at similar rates, suggesting the difference comes from converting partial completions into full completions rather than avoiding interruptions.

Statistical significance — Bonferroni-corrected (105 tests, p<0.00048): Alignment gap is significant (p=0.000328, d=−0.20). Failure rate (p=0.002) and completion rate (p=0.018) significant at p<0.05 but not after correction. Satisfaction and dissatisfaction differences are not statistically significant. The strongest signals in this study are behavioral (how models work) rather than qualitative (whether they succeed).

LLM-annotated dissatisfaction is extremely low for both models (<0.4%). Satisfaction and dissatisfaction differences between models are not statistically significant. A more direct accuracy signal—edit timeline analysis measuring how often users correct model output—is presented in Section 8.

7. Parallelization & Directive Compliance

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
MetricDistribution4.54.6
“Run in parallel” tasks
A
6
B
2
 6 2
Agents spawned per directive
A
8.3
B
3.5
 50 total 7 total
Background tasks from directive
A
0
B
6
 0 6
The parallelism paradox: Opus 4.5 responds to “run in parallel” by spawning more agents (8.3 per task vs 3.5) but runs them all in the foreground—zero background tasks. Opus 4.6, given the same directive, spawns fewer agents but actually backgrounds 6 of 7, achieving true concurrent execution. The model that appears more parallel (more agents) is less parallel in practice.

The “use agents” directive shows a similar pattern. Opus 4.5 spawns agents reliably (49 across 13 tasks, avg 3.8) but backgrounds only 9. Opus 4.6 barely engages with the directive at all—just 1 task, 2 agents, no backgrounding—likely because it already uses subagents autonomously and treats the directive as redundant.

8. Edit Accuracy

Satisfaction metrics capture user perception but not code accuracy. A more direct signal: how often does the agent rewrite its own code? Edit timeline analysis tracks every Edit and Write tool call per session, detecting when a later edit’s old_string overlaps with an earlier edit’s new_string on the same file.

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
MetricDistribution4.54.6
Total edits analyzed2,880720
Self-corrections
A
4.5%
B
6.1%
 13144
Error recovery
A
11.5%
B
9.4%
 33068
User-directed corrections
A
8.9%
B
0.6%
 2564
Iterative refinement
A
39.7%
B
12.6%
 1,14491

Classification

Each detected overlap is classified by context:

  • Self-correction: Agent rewrites its own output within the same task, no intervening error—catching and fixing its own mistakes unprompted.
  • Error recovery: Same task, but a tool error (test failure, syntax error, compilation failure) occurred between the original edit and the rewrite.
  • User-directed correction: The rewrite occurs in a later task, and the intervening user message contains dissatisfaction signals (“wrong”, “revert”, “fix that”, etc.).
  • Iterative refinement: Sequential edits to the same region without error signals or dissatisfaction—normal iterative development.

Self-correction rates are comparable (4.5% vs 6.1%), meaning both models catch their own mistakes at similar rates. Error recovery is also comparable (~9–12%). The critical difference is user-directed corrections: users had to ask Opus 4.5 to fix its work 16× more often (8.9% vs 0.6% of edits). This is the strongest accuracy signal in the dataset—it measures how often the model produces output that the user explicitly rejects.

Opus 4.5’s higher iterative refinement rate (39.7% vs 12.6%) reflects its different workflow: more sequential passes through the same code regions, producing more opportunities for edits to overlap. Opus 4.6’s research-first strategy appears to reduce the need for iterative rework.

Bottom line: Both models self-correct at comparable rates (~5%), but users correct Opus 4.5 edits 16× more often. Opus 4.6’s research-first approach and higher token expenditure translate into fewer corrections needed from the user—its code is more likely to be right the first time.

9. Planning: Correlation vs Causation

Opus 4.5 Opus 4.6
MetricDistribution4.54.6
Planning adoption rate
A
1.7%
B
15.7%
 6 tasks 34 tasks
Autonomous planning
A
50.0%
B
88.2%
 3 of 6 30 of 34

Opus 4.6 uses planning mode 9.2× more frequently, and 88% of that planning is self-initiated rather than user-requested. Yet the alignment benefit is minimal: planned tasks score only +0.04 above unplanned tasks.

Common cause, not direct effect: Planning doesn’t cause better outcomes—it co-occurs with the model’s general thoroughness. The same disposition that leads Opus 4.6 to plan also leads it to explore more, use more subagents, and investigate before acting. Planning is a symptom of caution, not the mechanism of quality. Forcing planning onto a model that doesn’t naturally adopt it is unlikely to help.

10. Model Profiles

Opus 4.5 — The Executor

Strategy: Act first, adjust as needed. Jumps to implementation with minimal upfront research.

Subagents: 50% general-purpose (implementation workers), 32% Explore. Primarily user-directed (72%).

Planning: Rarely uses planning mode (1.7%). Distributes research evenly through the task.

Strength: Efficient on trivial and simple tasks. Lower tool overhead. Stable performance across session lengths.

Risk: Higher failure rate on complex tasks. May miss edge cases that upfront research would catch.

Opus 4.6 — The Explorer

Strategy: Research first, implement in focused bursts. Front-loads investigation before touching files.

Subagents: 72% Explore (read-only research), 16% general-purpose. Overwhelmingly autonomous (85.5%).

Planning: Frequently self-initiates planning (15.7% of tasks, 88% autonomous).

Strength: Higher completion rate (+6.2pp), lower failure rate (−5.8pp). Best in short, focused sessions.

Risk: Higher tool overhead (55% more calls). Performance degrades in long sessions (−0.57 alignment over 9+ tasks).

Routing Recommendations

Task TypeRecommendedRationale
Trivial / simple tasksEither (slight edge: 4.5)Opus 4.5 is more efficient; 4.6’s research overhead adds cost without proportional benefit
Complex / major tasksOpus 4.6Higher alignment, front-loaded research catches requirements that 4.5 may miss
RefactoringOpus 4.616× fewer user-directed corrections; research-first approach reduces rework
Investigation / researchOpus 4.6Natural fit with research-first strategy; autonomous Explore agents excel here
Long sessions (9+ tasks)Either4.6 degrades faster but still scores higher (2.96 vs 2.85); consider session-break discipline
Parallel executionOpus 4.6Actually backgrounds tasks; 4.5 spawns more agents but runs them sequentially

11. Methodology

Session Logs421 sessions
→
Task Extraction2,395 tasks
→
LLM Annotationcomplexity, sentiment
→
Behavioral Analysissubagents, planning
→
Edit Timeline3,600 edits tracked
→
Statistical Tests105 comparisons

Each Claude Code session was segmented into tasks based on user-message boundaries and topic shifts. An LLM annotator classified each task for complexity, type, sentiment, completion status, and alignment score (1–5 scale). Behavioral metrics—subagent usage, planning, parallelization—were extracted from tool-call logs.

Edit timeline analysis tracked 3,600 Edit/Write tool calls across all sessions, building per-file content ownership maps to detect when a later edit’s old_string overlaps with an earlier edit’s new_string. Overlaps are detected via three tiers (exact match, containment at ≥30% ratio, and Jaccard line overlap) and classified by context (self-correction, error recovery, user-directed, iterative refinement).

Statistical testing: 105 tests were conducted: chi-square (categorical), Mann-Whitney U (continuous), proportion tests (rates). Bonferroni-corrected threshold: p<0.00048. Only three findings survive correction: tool calls per task, tools per file, and alignment score. Significance notes appear inline in each section.

Development Process

This analysis was developed iteratively. Several approaches were tried and abandoned when they proved unreliable:

Automated dissatisfaction detection (abandoned as primary signal): Initial LLM-based sentiment classification flagged 7–9% dissatisfaction for both models. LLM-agent audit of all 59 flagged cases revealed 73–93% false positive rates—the classifiers were fooled by task-coordination language (e.g., “fix” in subagent prompts). This approach was replaced by edit timeline analysis, which detects self-corrections mechanistically rather than through sentiment proxies.

LLM quality judgement (dropped): An LLM judge was asked to compare code quality between models. The results were unreliable—the judge lacked sufficient context to evaluate whether code met domain requirements, and produced confident but ungrounded assessments. This section was removed entirely rather than presented with caveats.

Refactoring routing recommendation (revised): Early signals suggested Opus 4.5 was better for refactoring, based on four false-positive dissatisfaction flags and small sample sizes. Sentiment detection and git retention both proved unreliable. Edit timeline analysis provided a direct mechanistic signal: tracking every edit across all sessions revealed that users correct Opus 4.5 edits 16× more often (8.9% vs 0.6%), reversing the initial recommendation.

Limitations

Single user: All data comes from one developer’s workflow. Results may not generalize to other users, codebases, or task distributions.

Observational, not experimental: Tasks were not randomly assigned to models. Opus 4.6 was used later chronologically and on different (often harder) tasks, confounding model effects with task effects.

Complexity confound: Opus 4.6’s higher proportion of complex tasks (11.9% vs 8.2%) inflates its resource usage metrics and may suppress its satisfaction scores relative to what it would achieve on equivalent tasks.

Sample asymmetry: The 5.6:1 ratio (2,035 vs 360 tasks) means Opus 4.5 estimates have narrower confidence intervals. Effect sizes for Opus 4.6 are less precise.

LLM-in-the-loop analysis: All task classification, sentiment analysis, and dissatisfaction auditing was performed by LLM agents (Claude Haiku and Sonnet), with human review of outputs and skepticism-driven re-auditing. No classification was done by hand.

Claude Code Early Access Program · Single-user behavioral analysis · February 2026
